metadata.case_name: Hans Muller v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Petitioner Hans Muller, a West German subject, arrested by Calcutta Police on 18th September 1954 and placed under preventive detention by West Bengal Government under section 3(1) of Preventive Detention Act 1950 with view to making arrangements for his expulsion from India.

Grounds of detention served on petitioner on 22nd September 1954. Second ground: petitioner is foreigner under Foreigners Act 1946, detention necessary under section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act until appropriate order of expulsion from Central Government.
On 19th September 1954, petitioner wrote to Consul-General of West Germany at Calcutta requesting early interview, which was granted.
On 21st September 1954, petitioner wrote to West Bengal Government requesting immediate repatriation from India and arrangements for transmission out of India.

On 9th October 1954, Calcutta Police handed petitioner's passport to West German Consul at Consul's request. Passport issued by West German Government at Nuremberg on 27th November 1953 with visas including Indian visa conditioned 'while the passport is valid'. Consul endorsed: 'Valid only for the return voyage to the Federal Republic of Germany until the 8th January 1955'. Petitioner complains this invalidated other visas and passport ceased validity after 8th January 1955.

On 9th October 1954, West German Government wrote to West Bengal Government: warrant of arrest issued against petitioner in West Germany for frauds, legal proceedings pending; similar charges in Lebanon and Egypt. Will apply for extradition through diplomatic channels. Request provisional warrant of arrest to detain until extradition. Arranged repatriation by German boat KANDELfels arriving Calcutta on 19th October 1954. All expenses borne by West German Government.

Secretary to West Bengal Government noted on receipt of letter: 'I suppose there would be no objection to our keeping Muller in detention till the 19th instant. We must issue order of his release as soon as his boat is ready to sail.'
West Bengal Government had no power to deport petitioner; only Central Government could. No expulsion orders passed by Central Government up to 20th October 1954.
On 20th October 1954, petitioner applied to High Court of Calcutta for writ of habeas corpus under section 491 CrPC. High Court dismissed petition on 10th December 1954.
Petitioner filed present petition to Supreme Court under Article 32 on 10th January 1955 on same grounds.
Attorney-General stated expulsion orders made and signed by Central Government but held in abeyance pending decision of this petition.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 3(1)(b) of Preventive Detention Act 1950 is ultra vires Constitution on grounds: contravenes Articles 21 and 22; contravenes Article 14; beyond legislative competence of Parliament.
Whether section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act is a law of preventive detention within meaning of Article 22(3), or contravenes Article 22(1) and (2).
Whether detention order made in bad faith, particularly after West German Consul's letter, to facilitate handover for extradition without formalities.
Whether State Government can detain under s.3(1)(b) in anticipation of Central Government's expulsion order.
Distinction between expulsion under Foreigners Act and extradition under Extradition Act, and whether government can choose expulsion despite extradition request.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act ultra vires as contravenes Articles 21 and 22.
Section 3(1)(b) contravenes Article 14 by differentiating between classes of foreigners, excluding certain British subjects.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14 Constitution; definition in s.2(a) Foreigners Act 1946

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3(1)(b) beyond legislative competence of Parliament.
Section 3(1)(b) not law of preventive detention under Article 22(3), so violates Article 22(1) and (2).

Detention in bad faith: real object to keep in custody for handover to West Germany on boat without extradition formalities; after Consul's letter, purpose changed to aid extradition or informal handover.
State Government cannot detain for expulsion arrangements as only Central Government can expel; arrangements must follow expulsion order.

respondent_arguments.text: Legislative competence from Entry 9 Union List (preventive detention connected with Foreign Affairs) read with Entry 10 (Foreign Affairs).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 9, 10 Union List; also Entries 17,19 List I, Entries 9 List I, 3 List III

respondent_arguments.text: Section 3(1)(b) complies with Articles 21,22; enacted to align Foreigners Act powers with Constitution.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 21,22; Foreigners Act s.4(1); Preventive Detention Act

respondent_arguments.text: Detention preventive to prevent evasion of expulsion, especially with criminal charges.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act s.3(1)(b); Foreigners Act s.3(2)(c), s.11(1)

respondent_arguments.text: State can detain in anticipation; Act confers power on State and Centre.
Classification of foreigners reasonable, does not offend Article 14; petitioner not aggrieved by British subject distinction.
Expulsion orders made but held in abeyance; bad faith question academic as no service yet. No change in purpose post-Consul letter.
Expulsion and extradition distinct; government can choose expulsion, foreigner leaves free man.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Foreigners Act; Extradition Act s.3(1); Articles 19,21

court_reasoning.text: Legislative competence clear under Entry 9 Union List (preventive detention for reasons connected with Foreign Affairs) read with Entry 10; deals with relations with foreign countries regarding subjects abroad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislation on detention/expulsion of foreigners brings Union into relation with foreign country.

court_reasoning.text: Complies with Articles 21,22; procedure established by law. Section 3(1)(b) aligns pre-Constitution Foreigners Act powers with Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detention to prevent breach/evasion of expulsion order is preventive.

court_reasoning.text: State Government can detain in anticipation of Central expulsion order; Act expressly confers power on State for arrangements including reference to Centre.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Necessary for timely action amid international complications.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of Article 14; reasonable classification of foreigners excluding certain British subjects; petitioner not aggrieved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only aggrieved persons can challenge under Article 32.

court_reasoning.text: Detention not in bad faith; order predated Consul letter; Secretary's note not indicative of government mind. No evidence of purpose change.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Original purpose for expulsion arrangements persists.

court_reasoning.text: Expulsion under Foreigners Act distinct from extradition; unfettered discretion to expel foreigner without formalities; leaves as free man, unlike extradition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government can choose expulsion despite extradition request; no obligation to extradite.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3(1)(b) is preventive detention related to Act's purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Includes ancillary rights to enforce expulsion.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act and section 3(2)(c) Foreigners Act intra vires Constitution.
Detention under s.3(1)(b) by State valid even in anticipation of Central expulsion order.
Expulsion and extradition distinct; government may expel foreigner under Foreigners Act without extradition formalities.

statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes detention of foreigner for expulsion arrangements; intra vires.

statutes_cited.relevance: Confers expulsion power on Central Government; definition of foreigner; ancillary enforcement rights.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Protects liberty; legislative competence for preventive detention, foreign affairs, expulsion; equality.

statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates extradition separately from expulsion; discretionary.

statutes_cited.relevance: Habeas corpus application to High Court.

outcome.summary: Court upheld validity of section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act, rejected all challenges to vires, legislative competence, Article 14, and bad faith; detention lawful for expulsion arrangements.

key_quotes.text: "Preventive detention for reasons connected with Foreign Affairs."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for legislative competence under Entry 9.

key_quotes.text: "The most effective method of preventing a breach of the order and ensuring that it is duly obeyed is by arresting and detaining the person ordered to be expelled until proper arrangements for the expulsion can be made."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In the case of expulsion, no idea of punishment is involved... the person expelled leaves India a free man."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Foreigners Act confers the power to expel foreigners from India. It vests the Central Government with absolute and unfettered discretion."
key_quotes.speaker: court
